keyTakeAways: Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man, was convicted of raping two women in northern Utah in 2008, with the first conviction occurring in August 2025 and a second sentencing scheduled for November 2025.
Rossi faked his death in 2020, claiming he died of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, which led to widespread public misinformation and allowed him to evade capture for years.
He was identified through a DNA match from a decade-old rape kit, part of Utah’s effort to clear a backlog of untested cases, which is a significant step in addressing sexual violence.

Rossi used multiple aliases, including Arthur Knight, and evaded authorities by living in Rhode Island and later fleeing to Scotland, where he was arrested due to distinctive tattoos recognized by Interpol.
The victim described the trauma of the assault and the psychological damage, emphasizing a plea for accountability and safety, which underscores the human cost of sexual violence.
Utah law allows for a range of sentencing, and Rossi received a sentence of five years to life in prison, reflecting the severity of the crimes and his flight risk.
He previously faced sex-related charges in Ohio and failed to register as a sex offender in Rhode Island, indicating a pattern of legal evasion and repeat offenses.
Rossi did not testify during the trial and maintained his innocence, claiming the victims were lying, while prosecutors argued he posed a danger to public safety.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A Utah judge sentenced Nicholas Rossi, who faked his death in 2020 to evade arrest on rape charges, to a prison term of five years to life. Rossi, previously known as Nicholas Alahverdian, was identified through a decade-old DNA match from a rape kit backlog in Utah. After being arrested in Scotland due to distinctive tattoos recognized by Interpol, he was extradited to Utah and convicted of raping two women in 2008. Prosecutors argued he was a flight risk and a serial abuser, while Rossi maintained his innocence and claimed the victims were lying. The victim described the trauma of the assault and emphasized a plea for accountability and safety. Rossi, who used multiple aliases and lived in Rhode Island, previously faced sex-related charges in Ohio and failed to register as a sex offender. The case highlights the challenges of addressing sexual violence and the importance of closing rape kit backlogs to bring perpetrators to justice.
title: Man accused of faking his own death and fleeing the US after rape charges gets at least five years in prison
